awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Localized Frontal Curing-Assisted 3D Printing of Thermosetting Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a collaborative research project on a novel 3D printing method for thermosetting polymers, localized frontal curing-assisted 3D printing. Thermosetting polymers are widely used in aircraft, space shuttles, cars, boats, bridges, furniture, and so on. Currently available methods to manufacture thermosetting polymer parts include conventional molding and newly-developed mold-free 3D printing. These methods involve two steps: deposition processing and post-processing curing that are both energy-intensive and time-consuming. In localized frontal curing-assisted 3D printing, deposition and curing are completed simultaneously in a one-step process. An external heat source is used to initialize the curing process and the heat produced by the exothermic curing reaction enables curing to self-propagate through the material as it is deposited. The new method has the potential to impact product design, assembly, and the manufacture of products using thermosetting polymers. As a result it could potentially lead to significant changes and increased competitiveness in many industries of national interest, such as the automotive, aerospace, and marine industries. This project will engage graduate and undergraduate students in the research activities thus preparing them for the advanced manufacturing workforce. Outreach activities based on the research will be used at high school summer camps and for online videos to educate students and the general public about advanced manufacturing.    

There are four research objectives: (1) to determine effects of curing agent concentration and printing slice size on frontal velocity and front propagation distance; (2) to understand relationships between localized frontal velocity, viscoelastic behavior of thermosetting resins, and geometric fidelity of printed structures; (3) to test the hypothesis that a specific range of frontal velocity will result in higher interlayer bonding strength; and (4) to reveal effects of localized frontal velocity on the mechanical performance of printed structures. To achieve these objectives, the research team will employ both theoretical and experimental approaches. Specifically, effects of curing agent structures and concentration on frontal curing velocity and front propagation distance will be modelled and simulated based on the reaction kinetics and then verified by high-resolution infrared camera. Viscoelastic behavior of thermosetting resins will be studied via real-time rheology characterization and data fitting. Effects of frontal velocity on interlayer bonding strength and mechanical performance of printed structures will be revealed by experimental tests and statistical analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Frontal curing (FC) is an emerging self-sustainable exothermic reaction that attracts increasing attention due to its reduced curing time from traditionally several hours to several minutes or even several seconds. FC-enabled additive manufacturing (FCAM) provides a rapid and energy-efficient manufacturing method for thermosets and their composites, which can be in-situ printed and cured without requiring ovens or autoclaves. Although some efforts on the predictive modeling of FC reactions have been reported, it is still unclear how the FC reaction kinetics may affect the resin self-propagation and continuous printing processes in FCAM. In this project, Finite element analysis (FEA) is used simulate the FCAM process of epoxy resin and its composites consisting of continuous or discontinuous carbon fiber (cCF/dCF). The curing kinetic and thermal diffusion equations are coupled and solved in 3D domains using COMSOL Multiphysics.

This study outlines the crucial factors for FCAM and clarifies how the frontal velocity, frontal temperature, and degree of cure in FCAM are influenced by different printing orientation, material compositions and various reaction kinetic parameters. The FEA results show that 20wt% cCF/epoxy composites with an activation energy of 60 KJ/mol exhibit a frontal velocity of 4.3 cm/min and a frontal temperature of 288°C during the continuous FCAM process, which are consistent with the experimental results. Case studies on different self-supportive spiral structures and a 6-meter wind blade tip were carried out to provide a guideline of material design and process control for scalable FCAM of 3D complex geometries.

Intellectual merit: This project fills the knowledge gap of FC reaction kinetics in additive manufacturing of thermosetting polymers and their fiber composites. Specifically, the effect of material composition and curing kinetics on the frontal velocity and maximal frontal temperature will be disclosed. This work will reveal the desirable print velocity and boundary conditions to sustain continuous printing and self-curing. Finally, this research will also provide groundbreaking knowledge on the effect of material composition on the crosslinking degree in as-printed filaments. 

Broader Impacts: This project leads to a rapid and energy-efficient additive manufacturing of high-performance thermosetting polymers and composites thermoset, which can be widely adopted by diverse industries, such as automobile, aerospace, marine industries. This technology can save tons of energy and greatly reduce manufacturing time of thermosetting polymers, and thus will open a new door for design and manufacturing of high-performance lightweight composite structures. Students who are members of underrepresented groups have been supported to work on the proposed cutting-edge research. The FEA simulation results have been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate curriculums. Research results have been broadly disseminated through annual reports to NSF, presentations at yearly ASME conferences, and journal publications. 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/09/2024
Modified by: Jingjing Qiu
